sense.name: the spiral firing tube of a gun
sense.commentary: BARREL[+artifact][+tube][+spiral][+firing][+gun] Note: refers to a spiral tube for propagating something along.
sense.examples: The robber pointed the barrel of his gun at the bank clerk. The stunt pilot did three barrel rolls in his aerobatic plane. (a spiral course)

sense.name: a cylindrical container
sense.commentary: BARREL[+artifact][+container][+cylindrical][+tapered] Note: does not focus on the substance being contained (see Sense 4)
sense.examples: These wine barrels are made of new French oak. We need to move these old barrels out of the warehouse. The barrel of a timepiece is a cylindrical metal box that contains the main spring. It's just another piece of pork barrel legislation. (figurative extension)

sense.name: having a bulging, cylindrical shape
sense.commentary: BARREL[+shape][+cylinder][+bulging] Note: refers to anything with a shape like a barrel, does not imply a container
sense.examples: The great Italian basso has a barrel chest and a thick neck. (shaped like a barrel) This is a type of large barrel cactus. (shaped like a barrel)

sense.name: a quantity, a unit of capacity
sense.commentary: BARREL[+quantity][+unit][+capacity][+oil/+beer/+pork] Note: focus is on how much substance is in the container, not the container itself (Sense 2)
sense.examples: Today oil was trading at over $70US a barrel. (a quantity) How many gallons are there in a barrel of beer? 18th-century sailing ships carried many barrels of salted pork for provision.

sense.name: the loins and belly of a four-legged animal
sense.examples: The red stallion was long-legged with a wide barrel. The pigs lowered their barrels into the cooling mud.

sense.name: cash only, no credit given or taken
sense.examples: This flea market takes cash on the barrel. John bought his new Mercedes on the barrel.

sense.name: being in a disadvantageous state
sense.examples: The French have them over a barrel in regards to this situation. John has me over a barrel in this chess game.
